â[A] layered account of a woman reckoning with love and violence at onceâ¦[Not] a flippant exposÃ© of childhood stardom, nor an angry diatribe directed at an abuser. This complexity is what makes Iâm Glad My Mom Died feel realâ¦Some supposed literary types will think the immense popularity of Iâm Glad My Mom Diedâthe hardcover initially sold out at many major bookstoresâis merely the result of McCurdyâs former stardom and modern cultureâs thirst for a sensational take. With its bold headline and bright cover featuring a smirking McCurdy holding a pink urn, the book feels deliberately marketed for virality, perfect for sharing on the internet and catching the eye of bookstore browsers. Iâve mentioned the title of this memoir to some people who have dismissed it out of hand, remarking that being glad oneâs parent is dead is crude and a sentiment that should be kept to oneself. But those people havenât read the book. McCurdy takes her time to remember difficult and complex moments of her life, staying true to her younger self while ultimately trying to come to terms with who she is as an independent adult. Itâs a triumph of the confessional genre.ââNina Li Coomes, The Atlantic

âNot many people rise to her level of fame or are so deeply abused, but McCurdyâs narrative will feel familiar to anyone who has navigated poverty and trauma. Taking advantage of the store discount at your dadâs retail job, tuning out screaming matches between parents, avoiding calls from debt collectors â¦ this is what childhood is like for millions of Americans. Like many, I recognized myself in her words.ââSabrina Cartan, Slate

âUnflinchingâ¦This yearâs most candid bookâ¦I'm Glad My Mom Died made me laugh; it made me cry. It's such a funny, dark, moving, honest, real, uncensored book, and it's unlike anything I've ever read.ââMary Elizabeth Williams, Salon

â[The] number-one New York Times-bestselling memoir that has also achieved pop-cultural phenomenon statusâ¦I'm Glad My Mom Died is more than source material for a deluge of headlines about Grande and the slimy advances of a Nickelodeon svengali McCurdy calls simply âThe Creator.â McCurdy distinguishes herself from standard-issue celebrity memoir fare with a vivid, biting, darkly comic tone and an immersive present tense.ââMichelle Ruiz, Vogue

âFor McCurdy, this book isn't just her writing debut. It's a reckoning with guilt and grief after her mother's premature death. It's healing from multiple eating disorders and processing decades of trauma. It's finally doing what she wants for the first time: not acting. Writingâ¦Healing from trauma looks different for everyone: For McCurdy, writing this memoir symbolized empowerment over her narrative. And understanding that it's OK not to forgive her late mother provided her peace.ââJenna Ryu, USA Today

âJudging simply by the shocking title of Jennette McCurdyâs debut memoir, Iâm Glad My Mom Died, you may think the book is a no-holds-barred, scathing takedown of her mother and everyone else who perpetuated the horrifying upbringing that the former iCarly star endured, but youâd be wrong. McCurdyâs book is certainly revealing, describing the abuse she endured from her mother, who pushed her into acting at age 6, then guided her directly into an eating disorder and much worse until her death in 2013. But beyond that, itâs a measured, heartbreakingly poignant, and often laugh-out-loud-funny memoir with McCurdy showing more sympathy for her complicated mother than most people could even imagine mustering. However, what is perhaps most important about her memoir, which is smart, well-written, and powerful, is just how much hope and help it will surely provide to those suffering similar abuses right now.ââScott Neumyer, Shondaland

âThe new memoir from former child star Jennette McCurdy has an attention-grabbing title: Iâm Glad My Mom Died. Over the course of the book, McCurdy, who built her name on Nickelodeonâs iCarly and Sam and Cat, more than makes her case, detailing years of her motherâs mental and physical abuse. The result is a detailed look at a very specific and individual childhood of horrors, but it also points to a major systemic problem. Iâm Glad My Mom Died doubles as a damning indictment of the child star systemâ¦She paints a vivid picture of child stardom as a system in which children find themselves turned into walking piles of other peopleâs cash, and summarily dismantled when they lose their value. Itâs damning both for the horrors she experienced as an individual and the systemic failures to which her story points.ââConstance Grady, Vox

âMcCurdyâs book must be written by someone. Why? It must be done because there is someone out there right now who truly believes that life will never be any different. They truly believe that they will live under their parentâs thumb, never have the life they wanted, not trust their own agency, their own minds, and people like Jennette exist to tell them: You are not wrong, you can trust yourself. You can do this too.ââErin Taylor, Observer

âA stunning memoirâ¦[McCurdy] reveals herself to be a stingingly funny and insightful writer, capable of great empathy and a brutal punchline. Itâs a document not just of all sheâs endured, but also of the wisdom she accrued along the way.ââSam Lansky, Time

âA coming-of-age story that is alternately harrowing and mordantly funny.ââDave Itzkoff, The New York Times

â[A] magnum opusâ¦sharply funny and empathetic.ââAshley Spencer, The Washington Post

âMcCurdy strips away the candy-coated facade of her sitcom experiences.ââVanity Fair

â[The] US summer publishing sensation thatâin short, punchy sentences delivered with a high level of self-perceptionâcould transform the trauma memoir businessâ¦[T]he book, and the reception it has received, could return the focus of the trauma narratives to the mother and create new demand for mother-daughter accounts.ââEdward Helmore, The Guardian

â[An] explosive debutâ¦insightful and incisive, heartbreaking and raw, McCurdyâs narrative reveals a strong woman who triumphs over unimaginable pressure to emerge whole on the other side. Fans will be rapt.ââPublishers Weekly (starred review)

âMcCurdy asks readers a question: When and how does one rid oneself of the cage created by others and walk freely? Her stunning debut offers fierce honesty, empathy for those that contributed to her grief, and insights into the hard-fought attachments and detachments of growing older.ââBooklist (starred review)

âDelivered with captivating candor and grace.ââKirkus (starred review)

âJennette McCurdy is the queen of lemonade from lemons, using her trauma to weave a painfully funny story that also illuminates the commodification of teenage girls in America. An important cultural document just as much as a searingly personal one.ââLena Dunham

âJennetteâs road to finding herselfâremoved from the expectations of her motherâis impressively funny. She fuses nuanced relationships, complex grief, religious whiplash and Hollywood trauma into a bold story with a specific comedic voice.ââJerrod Carmichael

âHow can a book be so sad and also so funny? It's an art, and Jennette McCurdy has mastered it here. Iâm Glad My Mom Died is hysterical and heartbreaking and fascinating all at the same time.ââJenny Lawson, New York Times bestselling author of Furiously Happy: A Funny Book About Horrible Things and Broken (in the Best Possible Way)

âI'm Glad My Mom Died is furious, sad, brave, knowing, honest, heart-wrenching, and utterly compelling. McCurdy writes with a keen insight and startling compassion. Whether showing how dysfunction can seem normal to those most affected, the torture of eating disorders, or the mindfuck that is child stardom, McCurdy brings readers deep into the milieu so often hidden from outsiders. This is a beautifully crafted coming-of-age story as fearless as its author.â âLauren Hough, New York Times bestselling author of Leaving Isnât the Hardest Thing

âJennette McCurdyâs book is a coruscating picture of her life as a child actor, devastatingly honest and with great understanding of the psychology and emotions operating at a deep level. Itâs a riveting read, entertaining and very touching.ââHayley Mills, New York Times bestselling author of Forever Young

âJennetteâs career as an actor was simply a character in a much more important story. She is a natural writer with a wonderful sense of humor. Her story is heartbreaking with a nice balance of hopeful. I could not put this book down.ââLaraine Newman, original cast member of Saturday Night Live and author of May You Live in Interesting Times
